qas.question: What happened to geology during the Scientific Revolution?
What theory did Nicholas Steno discover?
What book did Thomas Burnet right in 1681?
What text did Burnet base his work off of?

context: Geology did not undergo systematic restructuring during the Scientific Revolution, but <a0_0>individual theorists made important contributions<a0_0/>. Robert Hooke, for example, formulated a theory of <a1_0>earthquakes<a1_0/>, and Nicholas Steno developed <a2_0>the theory of superposition<a2_0/> and argued that fossils were the remains of once-living creatures. Beginning with Thomas Burnet's <a3_0>Sacred Theory of the Earth<a3_0/> in 1681, natural philosophers began to explore the idea that the Earth had changed over time. Burnet and his contemporaries interpreted Earth's past in terms of events described in <a4_0>the Bible<a4_0/>, but their work laid the intellectual foundations for secular interpretations of Earth history.
